content.description:
A pretty straightforward wide crack, with enough hands and feet to make everything straightforward. Stay in the wide feature to the top.



To the right of the bolted line "Curtain Call, 5.10d". See picture topo. 

Turn off onto the Terry Fox monument and look for the rock wall immidiately on your right. The route is near the left of this rock wall.

Mix of sizes, potentially up to 4". FFA was done solo, not been led on gear yet. 2 bolt anchor on the face with rap rings.

climbs.name: Curtain Call
climbs.fa: Jared Miller, Sept 2022. FFA Jared Miller, Meagan Jung, Sept 2022

content.description:
Start climbing to the right of the line of bolts, finding holds and tricky feet to stand on a good rest to the right of the third bolt. Then make the cruxy traverse to the left, unlocking the beta to make your way to easier terrain. Finish by climbing the stepping ledges up and left to the bolted anchor on the top above, with a slightly runout last bolt and anchor in the easier terrain. Do not traverse right to the face anchor for "Car Jack 5.7"



Turn into the Terry Fox monument off the highway. The wall is immediately on your right. Park on the gravel pullout and look for the clean rock face on the left side of the wall. Curtain Call is to the right of Lens Flare and left of Car Jack. Look for the leftward slopping flake/ledges partway up the climb.

5 bolts and 2 bolt anchor on top with rap rings.

A perfect finger crack on a blank wall. Super short and bouldery, could be done with a pad or two, or led on gear. Requires good finger crack technique, or just really pumpy laybacking with smearing feet.



Drive in to the Terry Fox monument road. Continue past the blasted road cut and just before the road heads up to the monument and parking area, turn left down the previous access road, dirt and old asphalt. Continue to the end of this road, just before the highway. Walk right along the road clearing for ~100m, and keep an eye out for the finger crack in a left facing corner. There's a few opportunities to scramble up and set top rope.

Really small cams. A couple larger trees up top for anchor.

climbs.name: Lens Flare
climbs.fa: FA Kyle Brooks, FFA Jared Miller, Sept 2022

content.description:
A really enjoyable flaring hand crack. The crack pinches off in the few spots but face holds fill in the blanks and make for really creative and engaging climbing. Takes good gear, though the rest positions to place aren't always easy. 

Start by stepping up the shale band ledges and use some perfect hand jams to gain the positive hold in the crack above. Keep an eye outside the crack for additional holds as needed, and continue up as the crack flares and pinches off alternatingly. Once you've gained the large ledge, the anchor is up and to your right. The giant wedged block at the top was not able to be moved, but best to still be careful.

The top was bolted for top rope dry tooling by Kyle Brooks. It was recently scrubbed clean and is in great shape. This area of wall is used for dry tooling, so do not be surprised to see scratch marks. Beware, there is loose rock above all the climbs other than those currently cleaned. The rock quality at this area is very poor, a lot of cleaning required to make safe in summer. 



Turn off the highway to the Terry Fox Monument. Pull off the road before the road cut, near the long amphitheatre of crumbling rock on your right. The two climbs cleaned here so far are on the climbers left side of this bluff, just before a vertical section of chossy rock and before it all turns to crumbling shale. Refer to the pictures.

The easiest way to scramble up and set for top rope is around the far right side of the bluff, just look for the rampiest section and scramble up that and around.

2 bolt anchor with rap rings. Gear is C4 #1 and below, and will accept nuts in several spots.

A really enjoyable slabby balance game from bottom to top. The holds are still somewhat loose and sandy, should clean up by next rock season. 



This top rope only route is the set of anchors furthest on the climbers right, at the top of the crag. Access by scrambling around right to the top and look for the anchors, with rap rings, in the open flat section with little vegetation.

2 bolt anchors with rap rings at the top. Rock quality partway through the route (crumbly) does not allow for safe bolting on the face.

A pretty dirty and mostly neglected crack. There's a couple burly moves to get into the crack, depending on your height/reach. Takes good gear the whole way, hands to thin hands for jams. Used a couple trees up top to build an anchor and scrambled back around from the monument to get down. Pretty scrappy and short a decently fun crack.



Drive in to the Terry Fox monument road. Continue past the blasted road cut and just before the road heads up to the monument and parking area, turn left down the previous access road, dirt and old asphalt. Continue to the end of this road, just before the highway. Tweetie's Place is right on the rock wall to your right when facing the highway.

C4 #0.75 - #2, some material for tree anchors.

climbs.name: Underclass
climbs.fa: FA Kyle Brooks, FFA Jared Miller, Oct 2022

content.description:
A really fun and technical line running up the wall, combining finger locks, side pulls, crimps, awkward flaring jams and a beautiful V3 boulder problem at the top. It's probably going to get a single bolt to protect the face section just before the top out, as the last gear is below your feet and the boulder problem is fairly tricky. This last section is Spicy on lead, currently.

Step up onto the shale bands as ledges and make your way up to the first big jug. From there, find one of several ways past the undercling problem before starting up the sustained waving finger crack section to the ledge above. Once you've gained the ledge, find the sequence of face moves to move up and throw for the top.

The top was bolted for top rope dry tooling by Kyle Brooks. It was recently scrubbed clean of loose rocks, revealing a high quality route, by Tyler Ripku. This area of wall is used for dry tooling, so do not be surprised to see scratch marks. Beware, there is loose rock above all the climbs other than those currently cleaned. The rock quality at this area is very poor, a lot of cleaning required to make safe in summer.



Turn off the highway to the Terry Fox Monument. Pull off the road before the road cut, near the long amphitheatre of crumbling rock on your right. The two climbs cleaned here so far are on the climbers left side of this bluff, just before a vertical section of chossy rock and before it all turns to crumbling shale. Refer to the pictures.

The easiest way to scramble up and set for top rope is around the far right side of the bluff, just look for the rampiest section and scramble up that and around.


3 bolts protect until the very thin crack on the middle third, which takes small nuts or cams (I used black Totems). 1 more bolt on the face protecting the final boulder problem before the topout. 

2 bolt top anchor with rap rings

A small series of bluffs around the Terry Fox Monument outside town. There's a number of scrappy, short little climbs. For full info for any Thunder Bay crags, see Aric Fishman's guidebook: Thunder Bay Climbing.
